Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The management of Sara Lee is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. An Environment & Safety Administrator has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals. This site has developed and trained personnel to assist the Alameda County Fire Department to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies. The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Sara Lee employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



The Sara Lee plant covered by this RMP is located at 2411 Baumann Ave in San Lorenzo, California. The facility is divided into two areas: Raw and Ready to Eat. The Raw portion of the plant receives, processes, and prepares meats for cooking or curing. The Ready to Eat portion of the plant packages the prepared products.

Products from this plant include Gallo Salame® Italian Dry Salame and Pepperoni; Galileo® Italian Dry Salame, Pepperoni; Deli d'Italia® Italian Dry Salame, Genoa, Hillshire Farm® Hard Salami and La Italia® Italian Dry Salame, Pepperoni. 

-A stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is used for room cooling and process chilling. The potential total anhydrous ammonia charge to the system is 15,000 pounds. This ammonia refrigeration system is the only process at this site to which the RMP requirements are applicable.

The site includes a large processing building with administration offices; the refrigeration engine room; the shipping and receiving areas; and employee and visitor parking lots. Some refrigeration equipment and piping are located outdoors.

Emergency Response Program



Sara Lee has developed an Emergency Planning and Response document to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia release emergencies. The plan is maintained at the site's Safety Office. The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, provides detailed evacuation proceduresfor the control of ammonia releases. The control procedures include leak investigation, release isolation, shutting off equipment, closing valves, and other control actions that do not involve plant personnel entering an IDLH environment. 

-The Alameda County Fire Department will be used to respond to any catastrophic leaks. The plant has a trained Emergency Action Team (EAT) that is capable of providing basic first aid and non-confined space personnel rescues and escape in non-hazardous environments. The EAT is capable of providing technical support to the fire department in the event of a catastrophic ammonia leak.  In the event of a catastrophic leak, Sara Lee will evacuate and take initial life safety precautions.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The facility continues to update the RMP by conducting three-year audits and five-year Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidations.  The last three-year audit was in 2009 and the last PHA revalidation was in 2008.  The next three-year audit is scheduled for 2011 and the next PHA revalidation is scheduled for 2013.  In addition to a committed audit program, the facility also continuously strives to improve both its mechanical integrity program and employee training.  

-The facility has implemented Total Productive Maintenance (TPM), which will improve mechanical integrity by updating maintenance procedures and incorporating the latest in maintenance techniques and methodologies.  The facility is also developing a comprehensive Predictive Maintenance (PdM) Program that will utilize technologies such as thermography and vibra

tion analysis to improve the preventive maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  

-Refrigeration Technicians involved in ammonia operations and maintenance have obtained Level III Ammonia Operator Certification.  To improve the safety of the system, the facility is currently in the process of hiring additional technicians to ensure that the facility has 24-hour, 7 day a week coverage of the ammonia refrigeration system.
